auditor_team_names_and_positions Klaus Geiger, Project Manager and Lead Auditor, Rainforest Alliance; auditor_qualifications Klaus Geiger is a forester with professional experience in Latin America. As Carbon Services Staff Auditor with Rainforest Alliance Klaus conducts and leads carbon field audits for projects under six different carbon standards, including AFOLU, REDD+, and the VCS Double Approval Methodology. Prior to working with Rainforest Alliance, Klaus researched Sri Lankan non-timber forest products by documenting species composition and mapping spatial distribution in traditional agroforestry gardens, co-managed the 8,000 acre FSC-Certified Yale School Forest, promoted sustainable agriculture techniques for 3.3 years with the Peace Corps in Panama within the Comarca Ngäbe-Buglé and on the national level. Among other experiences, cruised timber for the U.S. Forest Service in Tahoe National Park. Klaus received his Masters of Forestry degree from the Yale University School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, and holds a Bachelors of Forestry from University of Missouri-Columbia. Klaus is fluent in Spanish and conversational in Sinhala.

risk_factor Project Managemen t: Shall be assessed using Table 1 of VCS AFOLU Risk Tool.; self-assessment_risk_rating -2; findings_(including_description_of_any_mitigation_activities_as_required_per_vcs_afolu_non-permanence_risk_tool_section_2.1.2.2) b c a) 0, justified. The project is not planting trees as part of the project activity generating GHG credits. ) 0, justified. Proponent asserts that ongoing enforcement not needed to prevent encroachment by outside actors. The project area, is surrounded by two protected areas and several communities. Legal testimony on archaeological evidence reviewed by the audit team does not clearly link historical inhabitation of the area by indigenous populations with modern day local communities. Nevertheless, surrounding communities earn their livelihoods through a mixture of ecotourism, subsistence farming, and small scale agricultural market participation. Some of the neighboring communities do apparently derive part of their livelihoods through activities which are no longer permitted within the project area (e.g. illegal firewood and/or NTFP collection). Though these activities do threaten the permanence of the carbon stocks found within the project area, they are unlikely to affect more than 50% of the stocks on which GHG credits have previously been issued. OBS 04/17 ) 0, justified. Proponent acknowledges the current management team has adequate experience, some of which is local to the region of Belize in which the project is located. The property caretaker and patrolmen are the employees that have the most direct interaction with the public, and they are entirely staffed by members of the neighboring communities. Furthermore, the PP asserts, and the audit team witnessed and can confirm, that the several members of the BCEP management team has more than 5 years’ experience in developing and; ncr/obs O BS 04/17 The project is justifying the lowest risk score for Project Management risk factor (b) with references to the future option of obtaining and enforcing a nationally recognized status as protected land. The auditors are unable to assess the validity of this statement considering that the project has not submitted evidence demonstrating that the project area would be eligible under such a program for legally protected status.

col_2 This report represents the final VCS Verification Audit Report for the Boden Creek Ecological Preserve Forest Carbon Project, for which Boden Creek Ecological Preserve is the proponent. The audit team, after extensive desk review, stakeholder interviews, field visit and observation, identified 06 Non- conformances, and 06 Observations communicated in this report through Nonconformity Reports (NCRs) and Observations (OBSs) in Appendix 1. The Non-conformances were successfully resolved and the project’s stated emissions reductions for the January 1st 2011 - Dec 31st 2015 5 have been verified to be free of material error to a reasonable degree of assurance. Project activities focus on forest protection, but include meeting with the local stakeholders surrounding the project area, engaging government officials and local NGOs, implementing the REDD project management and monitoring plans with the help of local partners and contracted staff, undertaking a periodic forest carbon inventory, and modelling deforestation. Activities implemented as part of the project to reduce deforestation include community outreach and employment of local community members as project forest guards or other project staff positions. The scope of the verification included the GHG project implementation; physical infrastructure, activities, technologies and processes of the GHG project; GHG sources, sinks and/or reservoirs; types of GHG’s; and time periods covered. The geographic verification scope was defined by the project boundary, the selected carbon pools, management activities, growth and yield models, forest inventory program, and contract periods. The audit process commenced on January 30th, 2017 with review of the project documentation by the audit team. The proponent provided the audit team with complete and well-justified documentation including the VCS Monitoring and Implementation Report (MIR) for the January 1st 2011 – December 31st 2015 monitoring period, and several dozen supporting documents. Following the pre-field audit document review and sampling plan development, the audit team conducted the field audit from March 20-23, 2017. Field audit activities included direct on-site observations, document review, and stakeholder interviews with local peoples, proponent staff, implementing partner staff, and relevant national government officials. Rainforest Alliance issued the draft audit report for the BCEP VCS verification on 14 April 2017. The project proponent developed responses to all identified Non- Conformity Reports (NCRs) and submitted them to the audit team on May 2nd. The Rainforest Alliance audit team then undertook a second review of project documentation and evidence provided by the project proponent, to which the project proponent responded by June 25th. A third review by Rainforest Alliance was completed, to which the project proponent responded by August 4th. Rainforest Alliance conducted a 4th review, and completed an internal report review on September 22nd. The audit team leader was a Rainforest Alliance Senior Carbon Auditor.
ncr#: The project has not demonstrated that the restrictive covenant exists on the property deeds to justify the lower risk scores.

obs Description of findings leading to observation:; 05/17_reference_standard_&_vcs_standard_3.6_requirement: The project has not indicated that feedback has been received since those initial consultations, including within the monitoring period for this verification— January 1st, 2011 through December 31st, 2015. Considering the active consent order arrangement between the Belizean government and the peoples represented by the Maya Leaders Alliance, and the possibility that the MLA’s clients in the future may assert land claims or customary use claims that overlap with the BCEP property, the project could stand to benefit from further engagement with local stakeholders. This is truer now that the project is exploring the possibility of reinitiating its ecotourism activities.

col_1 Ian Starr, Senior Internal Reviewer (RRA Reviewer), Rainforest Alliance; developing_a_plantation_growth_and_yield_model_for_the_center_for_tropical_research_and_education_(catie)_in_costa_rica,_and_preparing_forest_management_plans_for_the_honduran_forestry_development_cooperation._david_earned_his_phd_in_quantitative_forest_management_from_north_carolina_state_university,_where_he_conducted_spatial_optimization_analysis_for_wildlife_and_timber._he_holds_an_m.s._in_natural_resource_management_from_humboldt_state_university_and_his_b.a._in_environmental_biology_from_university_of_california,_santa_barbara._david_is_fluent_in_spanish. Ian’s role as Climate Technical Specialist in Rainforest Alliance’s Climate Program involves being an auditor for REDD+ projects for the voluntary carbon market, providing training on REDD+ and climate change to a broad range of groups worldwide, and providing technical leadership on adaptation and mitigation for agriculture and forestry projects. Ian is a forester and resource manager with personal and professional experience in North America, Central and South America, and Africa. His principal interests lie in improving conservation and forest management practices in tropical forests. He has collaborated on a variety of forestry and natural resource management projects in both Amazonia, and the temperate hardwood forests of the Northeastern United States. These projects have included modelling the carbon sequestration potential of various tropical agroforestry systems and designing and participating in several forest inventories in New England to plan timber sales based on natural regeneration. Ian received his Masters degree in Forestry from the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies with a focus on tropical forest and resource management, and received his B.A. from Colgate University where he concentrated in Native American Studies with focus on Central and South America. He is fluent in Spanish and Portuguese.

ncr#: Evidence Provided by Organization:; 04/17 The project proponent previously claimed that a “legally binding commitment” with FCO was in place from the beginning of the project to not deforest the property, or sell the property, or do anything else that would harm the outcome of the VCS project. The project submitted evidence to support this claim, but the project has now retracted the mitigation claim, thereby eliminating the source of the finding.

obs Observation:; 02/17_reference_standard_&_vcs_standard_3.6_requirement: The project should implement and maintain reports, logbooks, or electronic records detailing incidents that occur on the property, such as: encounters with trespassers; illegal dump sites; evidence of human activity by unauthorized peoples.

designing,_implementing,_and_monitoring_high_quality_ecosystem_management_projects_and_forest_carbon_projects. Risk of extreme weather events (e.g. floods, drought, winds): BCEP has hurricane occurrence recorded roughly every 50 to 100 years.; col_2 Low

pest_and_disease Significance; col_2 B Insignificant CEP has no recorded history of pest and disease attacks. The forests of the project area have a high diversity of tree species, and like other diverse tropical forests, are not known to be subject to catastrophic disturbance by insect pests or forest diseases. Forest pests and diseases as a source of risk are more relevant in temperate forests or plantations3, with low species diversity and consequently susceptible to extensive damage due to pest and disease outbreaks, which tend to be concentrated on single host species. Further, there is no history of catastrophic forest disturbance due to forest pests or diseases in the region.

ncr#: Findings for Evaluation of Evidence:; 04/17 The “Carbon Management and Agency Agreement” submitted by the project became effective September 1, 2009, and is between BCEP and FCO. In it, FCO agrees, as representative of BCEP, to “take all … actions to … observe the designated monitoring plan and restrict the use and development of the Property … in accordance with the rules and requirements of the applicable Project Standards used for such Project.” This would be the restrictive covenant that the proponent referred to. However, in order to justify the mitigation claim, the legally binding commitment must be for “the length of the project crediting period”, per the AFOLU Non-Permanence Risk Tool. The
